utterances: But why Halle Berry?
Unidentified Woman #2: She's everywhere!
Every...
But why?
Unidentified Woman #2: ...magazine.
Halle Berry.
Halle Berry.
Why?
Unidentified Woman #2: Halle Berry's got nappy roots, ya'll.
Unidentified Woman #1: I just want to know, is that a weave?
Unidentified Woman #2: She has a perm.
Unidentified Woman #1: Is it a weave?
Unidentified Woman #2: It's a perm.
Unidentified Woman #1: Is that really her hair, though?
Is it that long?
Unidentified Woman #2: Hell no!
(Unintelligible)...
Unidentified Woman #1: Okay.
Unidentified Woman #2: ...because my hair looks kind of like that when I had had a perm.
Unidentified Woman #1: Yeah.
Unidentified Woman #2: So I vote perm.
Even though I love gossiping about hair with other black women, I also realize our obsession with hair brings up questions about whether we're willing to conform to the mainstream culture.
When my family and I talk about adjusting to college life, they say, because I'm light-skinned and speak proper English, it will be easier for my classmates to accept me.
I don't know if it's that simple.
Right now, I'm thinking more about identity and leaning toward getting my hair locked.
For me, dreadlocks represent a liberated black person who made a choice not to conform.
It's not like I'm trying to be earth mother Afrocentric, like singers Erykah Badu and Lauryn Hill, but I may be ready to reinvent myself on my own terms.
Bianca Butler starts college later this month in Bronxville, New York.
Her story was produced by Youth Radio.
(Soundbite of music)
You're listening to MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Well, one week after the election, there is still no final result in the presidential race from Missouri.
The Show Me state is the only state that has not yet declared a winner.
As counties recount the votes, John McCain's lead in Missouri has shrunk to just under 5,000 votes of the 2.9 million cast.
That's a margin of 0.1 percent.
Matt Sepic of member station KWMU joins us from St. Louis.
And Matt, what's been going on during the recounting and revision of the tally in Missouri?
In St. Louis County, just in the last few days, election officials counted about 3,200 votes that for whatever reason were not initially counted on election night.
These were votes on electronic voting machines.
And something went wrong.
They weren't included in the final tally?
Yes, but we're not sure exactly what the problem was at that point.
Now, St. Louis County does not include St. Louis City, but it is, I believe, a Democratic-leaning county.
Yes, and it did go for Senator Obama in this election.
Matt, there were also about 7,000 provisional ballots that were cast on Election Day.
What's going on with those?
Those have not been counted yet.
Provisional ballots are cast if somebody goes to the polls and there are problems with the registration.
And once they get things sorted out with these electronic ballots, they will start looking into the provisional ballots.
There's about, as you said, about 7,000 of those.
And where are they from?
Those are primarily from Democratic-leaning areas as well, St. Louis and Kansas City.
The pattern, though, with provisional ballots often is that a large percentage of them get thrown out.
Only about 30 to 40 percent of provisional ballots are actually determined to be valid.
And assuming all of those - and I'm going to assume 40 percent here - just for a matter of argument went to Obama, McCain would still have about a 2,000 vote win here.
Well, are election officials giving any sense of when you will have a final result in Missouri?
The counties have another week to certify their results.
Then it will be another two weeks before the statewide results have to be certified by Missouri's secretary of state, Robin Carnahan.
So it could be after Thanksgiving before we have a final answer.
What are people in Missouri saying about the delay in the result?
Does it trouble people that Missouri is the one holdout state that still hasn't gotten a final tally?
From the top of the tram, the problem is obvious.
For long blocks along this busy, commercial strip in Annandale, Virginia, men stand in small clusters along the sidewalk.
A few years ago, they say this was a sellers' market.
Day laborers could choose whom they wanted to work for.
But now, more and more men are showing up for less and less work.
Fifty-nine-year-old Jose Maria says he can't take it much longer.
(Spanish spoken)
The other day, I told my wife on the phone, if I could just get a plane ticket.
However I can find the money for that, I'm coming back to El Salvador.
Like many here, Jose Maria does not have legal status, and does not want to use his last name.
He says he used to get steady landscaping jobs and sent $300 a month to his wife and youngest daughter.
But he's had no work and sent no money for four months now.
(Spanish spoken)
I'm asking myself, what am I doing here?
Look at all these people waiting for work.
It's a tragedy.
Jose Maria worries there's less money to be made back home, but if there's also no money here, he figures he should at least be with his family.
I think that we have to reconsider a lot of things.
Arnoldo Borja is with Legal Aid Justice Center, which advocates for day laborers.
Lately, he's become something of a social worker-cum-psychologist for these men.
When I talk to these guys about what is happening right now, it should be a good lesson, good lesson for us, for the recognition about what we have over there - family, friends.
Borja sees this return to family values, if you will, as a silver lining to the downturn.
Since October, he's driven two dozen men to the airport, all returning home.
Some were looking forward to getting closer to children they barely knew.
One young man confided he was a bit worried about having left his even younger wife back home alone for so long.
Borja hears more and more men talk of leaving, but it's not at all clear how big this trend is.
There is, I think, an equal number, if not many more day laborers, who have decided to remain and hunker down like many others in this country, and wait out the recession.
